questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with swelling and mild pain in his left leg for several years. Physical examination revealed bulky, stiff skin with inguinal lymphadenopathy in the left lower limb (image). What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Elephantiasis

Explanation:

 

Elephantiasis is the most likely diagnosis for this patient, who has had swelling and pain in their left leg for several years, coupled with skin findings, lymphadenopathy, and microfilariae of W. bancrofti on microscopic examination.

 

Filariasis:

  • Agent:
    • Wucheria bancrofti: Lymphatic filariasis
    • Brugia malayi: Brugian/Malayan filariasis
  • Endemic areas: Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Gujarat
     
  • Host:
    • Definitive: Man
    • Secondary/ intermediate: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans
       
  • Mode of Transmission: Bite of the mosquito (vector)
    • W. bancrofti: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans (polluted water)
    • B. malayi: Mansonia (ponds, lakes)
       
  • Incubation period: 8-16 months.
     
  • Transmission: Cyclo-developmental: The disease-producing organism undergoes vital cyclical changes in the arthropod vector but does not multiply there. 
  • Clinical features:
    • Asymptomatic Amicrofilariae: No symptoms, smear-negative
    • Asymptomatic microfilariae: No symptoms, smear-positive
    • Acute stage (few months): Fever, lymphadenitis, epididymo-orchitis.
    • Chronic Obstructive stage (>10 years): Hydrocele, chyluria, elephantiasis
    • Occult stage: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (hypersensitivity reaction) with absent microfilariae

 

Lepromatous leprosy (Option A) is characterized by numerous skin lesions (macules, nodules), thickened peripheral nerves (loss of sensation), and other organs.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis (Option C)  presents as bumps (nodules) that turn into large, raised, indurated ulcers with central crusting over time, which may heal spontaneously.

Trypanosomiasis (Option D), also known as sleeping sickness presents as painless chancre, maculopapular rash, hepatosplenomegaly, and daytime sleepiness.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented to the hospital with swelling and thickening of both legs. A thick blood film revealed the following image. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the diagnosis of this condition?

choices.text: Mass blood surveys with thick blood films are prepared between 10 AM to 2 PM
Drug provocation test has the highest specificity
Serological tests can differentiate between past and present infections
​​Rapid detection test is used as an investigation of choice for this condition

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Drug provocation test has the highest specificity

Explanation:

Diagnosis of filariasis

1.

Thick blood film
(Investigation of choice)

Nocturnal microfilariae are seen in blood between 10 PM to 2 AM (Option A)

Lymphatic filariasis

Brugian/Malayan filariasis

Large, smooth (graceful) curve with countable nuclei

Small, kinked at an acute angle with a long head and uncountable nuclei, 2 nuclei in the tail tip

2.

Rapid Detection Test
  • Also called the filarial strip test
  • Used for monitoring, mapping, and evaluation activities (Option D)

3.

Membrane filter concentration method
  • Most sensitive methods for detecting low-density microfilaraemia
  • Require specialized equipment.

4.

DEC provocation test:
  • A single oral dose of 100mg DEC followed by blood smear after 1 hour
  • Microfilariae can appear in the daytime.
  • Highest specificity (Option B)

5.

Serological tests
  • Cannot differentiate between past and present infection (Option C)

6.

Mass blood survey
  • Thick blood films for epidemiological Survey

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male presents with leg swelling and hydrocele on his left side. Blood tests reveal the presence of microfilariae of W. bancrofti. Which of the following statements regarding the management of the disease are false?

Statements:


	Biannual mass drug administration with triple-drug therapy reduces transmission.
	Effective MDA coverage should be >90% for 5-6 years.
	A total dose of 72 mg/kg diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is the drug of choice for treating active filariasis.
	Integrated vector management includes anti-larval and anti-adult measures for preventing filariasis.
	Ivermectin 150-200 mcg as a combination treatment is effective in killing microfilariae
questions.solution:
Correct answer:  A) 1 and 2

Explanation: 

Management of Filariasis

Treatment

Triple Drug therapy

  • Diethylcarbamazine (DEC): 6 mg/kg/day for 12 days +
  • Albendazole stat (400 mg: > 2 years, 200mg: < 2 years ) +
  • Ivermectin (150-200 mcg)
 

Acute dermato-lymphangio adenitis (ADLA):

  • Analgesics: Paracetamol
  • Antibiotics: no anti filarial drug
    • Uncomplicated: Amoxicillin, erythromycin
    • Severe: IV Penicillin

Prevention
  • Annual Mass Drug Administration (MDA):
    • Yearly triple drug therapy with DEC, albendazole and ivermectin
    • Coverage: >65% for 5-6 years
    • Lymphatic filariasis elimination strategy: microfilariae rate <1%
    • Conduct a filarial survey in all age groups before starting MDA and a TAS (transmission assessment survey) among the 6-7 years age group after MDA
    • Stop MDA if TAS < 2% followed by post-MDA surveillance with 2 more rounds of TAS
 
  • DEC Medication Salts:
    • 1- 4 gms of DEC is added per 1kg of salt in Maharashtra and Lakshadweep Islands
 
  • Vector Control (Integrated vector management):
    • Anti Larval: Larvicidal oil (pyrosene oil, fenthion, temephos)
    • Anti-adult: DDT (6 monthly), lindane, malathion (quarterly)
  • Aquatic plant removal: Water hyacinths, Pistia plants

Monitoring
  • Microfilaria rate:
    • Most sensitive indicator
    • Persons with microfilaria /20 mm3 of blood / total population × 100
    • Indicates prevalence of infection.
 
  • Filarial endemicity rate:
    • Persons with microfilaria + clinical diagnosis / Total population × 100
    • Indicates prevalence of disease.
 
  • Microfilaria density:
    • Percentage of microfilaria per unit volume of blood
    • Indicates intensity of infection (endemicity potential).
 
  • Average infestation rate:
    • Average microfilaria per positive slide
    • Microfilaria prevalence in the area

questions.text: A 30-year-old male farmer presents with worsening fever and weight loss for the last 2 months. Physical examination demonstrated significant hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests show pancytopenia and a positive rk39 test. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Liposomal amphotericin B

Explanation:

Treatment with liposomal amphotericin B is recommended for visceral leishmaniasis, which is most likely the cause of this patient's clinical symptoms (fever, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia), and a positive rk39 antigen.

 

Kala-azar/ Black sickness/Dum-dum fever/Sandfly disease/ Visceral Leishmaniasis

Organism

Protozoan

Epidemiology

Endemic in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal

Types
  • Visceral (Kala-Azar): L. donovani
  • Cutaneous: L. tropica (oriental sore/ delhi boil/ Aleppo button)
  • Mucocutaneous: L. braziliensis (espundia)
  • Post-kala-azar dermal (PKLD): Immune response

Reservoir
  • Humans (non-zoonotic)

Vector
  • Sandfly (Phlebotomus argentipes): has hairy wings.

Environmental
  • Peak outbreak: November to April

Mechanism of transmission
  • Bite of sandfly
  • Blood transfusion (rare)

Incubation period
  • 10 days to 2 years. (1-4 months average)

Clinical features
  • Visceral: Fever, Weight loss, Hepatosplenomegaly, Anemia.
  • Cutaneous: Painful skin ulcers
  • Mucocutaneous: Rapid mucosal destruction of nose and oropharynx
  • PKDL: Skin nodules filled with micro-organisms

Diagnosis
  • Rapid diagnostic kits: rk39-dipstick test.
    • Used for field surveys.
  • Biopsy (Gold standard): Leishmania Donovan bodies

Sandfly control measures
  • DDT: 1-2gm/m2.
  • BHC (benzene hexachloride)

Treatment
  • DOC: Single dose Liposomal amphotericin-B (LAMB)10 mg/kg
  • Alternatives:
    • Miltefosine + Paramomycin (Options B and D)
    • Pentamidine (Option C)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who works in flooded rice fields presents with a 5-day history of high fever, headache, and yellowing of the eyes. Physical examination demonstrated conjunctival redness and calf tenderness. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Leptospirosis

Explanation:

Leptospirosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with high fever, severe headache, muscle pain, calf tenderness, conjunctival suffusion, jaundice, and a history of exposure to flooded rice paddies.

Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Diagnosis
  • Clinical features
  • Darkfield examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

 

Dengue (Option A) typically presents with high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, rash, and bleeding tendencies with laboratory tests showing thrombocytopenia.

 

Malaria (Option B) presents with periodic fevers, jaundice, headache, and muscle pain. A blood smear shows intraerythrocytic plasmodium parasites.

 

Hepatitis A (Option D) causes jaundice and elevated liver enzymes but it is transmitted through contaminated food and water and is less associated with working in flooded paddies.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics is not recommended for the treatment of leptospirosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Ciprofloxacin

Explanation:

Ciprofloxacin, a bacterial DNA gyrase inhibitor, is ineffective for treating leptospirosis.

 

Management of Leptospirosis:

 

Treatment
  • DOC: Penicillin 6 million units daily. (OPTION B)
  • Alternate drugs:
    • Doxycycline (OPTION A)
    • Amoxicillin (OPTION C)
    • Ampicillin
    • Ceftriaxone

Prevention
  • Avoid contaminated water and use protective clothing
  • Livestock vaccination, proper waste disposal
  • Rodent control measures: Zinc phosphide

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the epidemiological features of Japanese Encephalitis is incorrect?

choices.text: The virus belongs to the Flaviviridae family
Humans are the primary reservoir hosts for the Japanese Encephalitis irus
Primary vectors for Japanese Encephalitis are Culex mosquitoes.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Humans are the primary reservoir hosts for the Japanese Encephalitis virus

 

Explanation:

Humans are not the primary reservoir hosts for the Japanese Encephalitis Virus.

The primary reservoirs are pigs and wading birds and humans are incidental hosts, meaning they can be infected but do not play a significant role in the transmission cycle because they do not produce enough virus in their blood to infect mosquitoes.

 

 

Epidemiological features of Japanese encephalitis

Agent

Japanese Encephalitis Virus (JEV), Group B Arbovirus

Virus Family: Flaviviridae (Option A)

Transmission Vector

Culex mosquitoes (Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui)
(Option C)

Hosts

Pigs (Amplifier Host)

Ardeid Birds: Pond herons, Ducks, Poultry (Maintenance Host)

Man: (Accidental or dead-end host)

  • Do not develop high enough viremia to infect mosquitoes.
  • Primarily children (below 15 years), but all ages susceptible
  • No man-to-man transmission.

Horses: Only animals that can manifest symptoms (Option D).

Environmental Factors

Geographic Distribution:

  • Southeast Asia, East Asia, and the Western Pacific regions.
  • India
    • Endemic: To 21 states but mainly includes Jharkhand, Bihar, West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Assam and Haryana
  • Seasonal Distribution:
    • Monsoon and post-monsoon period (varies by region)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from rural Uttar Pradesh presents with high fever, severe headache, vomiting, altered mental status, neck stiffness, and positive Brudzinski's sign. He is unvaccinated and lives near rice fields and pig farms during the monsoon season. What is the most likely diagnosis and the investigation of choice for confirmation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Japanese Encephalitis; IgM ELISA

 

Explanation:

Given the patient's symptoms and lack of vaccination, Japanese encephalitis is the most likely diagnosis. The investigation of choice for confirming JE is the IgM ELISA test for the JE virus, which detects specific antibodies in the patient's serum or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Japanese encephalitis

Incubation Period

5-15 days

Symptoms

Mild: fever and headache

Severe: high fever, headache, neck stiffness, seizures, coma

Case Fatality Rate

20-30% in severe cases

Long-term Sequelae

Neurological and psychiatric sequelae in 30-50% of survivors

Diagnosis

Serological tests (IgM ELISA), PCR

 

  • Bacterial meningitis (Option A) can cause similar symptoms (fever, headache, neck stiffness), and the specific epidemiological context (rice fields and pig farms) and season (monsoon) strongly suggest Japanese encephalitis.
    • Blood cultures are also less specific for CNS infections than CSF analysis and PCR.

 

  • HSV encephalitis (Option B) can present with similar symptoms, but given the epidemiological context (rice fields and pig farms during monsoon season), it is less likely.
    • The symptoms are more indicative of Japanese encephalitis.


 

  • Dengue fever (Option D) commonly presents with high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and sometimes a rash.
    • However, it does not typically cause neck stiffness or altered mental status indicative of central nervous system involvement.
    • Additionally, while dengue is prevalent in monsoon seasons, the specific history of living near rice fields and pig farms is more indicative of Japanese encephalitis.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the Live-attenuated JE vaccine except?

choices.text: Included in the national immunisation schedule.
Vaccination schedules include a primary series followed by a booster dose.
It can be administered to children as young as 6 months old.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Can be administered to children as young as 6 months old.

 

Explanation:

The JE vaccine is recommended for children and is administered starting at 9 months of age or older.

Japanese encephalitis vaccines

Types
  1. Inactivated vaccine (Nakayama)
  2. Live attenuated vaccine (SA-14-14-2), the mostly preferred
  • Diluent: Phosphate buffer since the JƐ vaccine is in powdered form.
  • The vaccine used to be included in the National Immunization Schedule(NIS) targeting high-risk regions.

      3. The killed vaccine in India is JENVAC - Kolar strain which is given IM                          injection. 

  • It has been added to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS).

Dosage

Administered 2 Doses

  • 1st: 9 months
  • 2nd: 6 to 24 months

Min Gap between 2 doses → 3 months, 0.5 ml (left arm)

Route: Subcutaneous

  • In case of non-immunized children :

Can be given to children < 15 years of age

questions.text: A 30-year-old non-immunized traveler returns from a trip to a tropical region and presents with a high fever, chills, severe headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice. Which of the following parameters is unsuitable for transmitting the suspected disease?

choices.text: Presence of monkeys in the area

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Temperature of climate ranging 18-24°C

 

Explanation:

Yellow fever transmission is less likely in cooler temperatures. Aedes mosquitoes thrive in warmer climates, typically between 24-36°C. Therefore, a climate with temperatures ranging from 18-24°C is unsuitable for transmitting yellow fever.

Yellow fever

Agent and Vector
  • Flavivirus transmitted primarily by mosquitoes
    • Aedes Mosquito (in urban settings)
    • Haemagogus (in jungle or forested areas)

Hosts
  • Primarily monkeys (Reservoir hosts)
  • Humans are (Incidental hosts) and can develop severe disease.

Environmental Features
  • Found in tropical and subtropical areas of Africa and South America, where mosquito vectors are prevalent.
  • Transmission occurs primarily in forested or jungle areas.
  • Typical Conditions:
  • Temperature: 24-36’C
  • Humidity: >60%

Clinical Presentation
  • Initial symptoms (acute phase, 3-6 days post-infection): fever, chills, headache, backache, muscle aches, loss of appetite.
  • Severe cases (toxic phase): jaundice, bleeding, organ dysfunction (liver, kidney).

Diagnosis
  • Based on clinical signs
  • Travel history to endemic areas
  • Confirmed by detection of YFV RNA or specific antibodies (IgM and IgG) in blood samples.

 

High humidity levels (>60%) (Option A) create favourable conditions for the breeding and activity of mosquitoes, including the Aedes species responsible for yellow fever transmission.

 

Aedes mosquitoes (Option C), transmit the virus through their bites, making this parameter crucial for the transmission of yellow fever.

 

Monkeys (Option D) serve as natural hosts for the yellow fever virus in sylvatic (jungle) cycles. Their presence indicates the potential for the virus to circulate in the environment, with mosquitoes acting as vectors to transmit it to humans.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the yellow fever vaccine are correct?


	Intradermal administration
	The recommended age for administration is 7 months or older.
	A booster dose is required every 10 years for continued immunity.
	The vaccine contains a live-attenuated virus.
	A yellow card is issued for travel.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 4 and 5

 

Explanation:

Yellow fever vaccine

Types
  • Live-attenuated vaccine (17D strain)
  • Diluent: lyophilized (freeze-dried) powder with saline solution.

Administration
  • Route: Subcutaneous
  • Dose: A single dose, 0.5 mL
  • Site: Deltoid muscle
  • Age for Administration: Recommended for individuals completed 9 months.
  • 6 months (outbreak situations)

Efficacy
  • Onset of Immunity: Within 30 days
  • Duration of Immunity: A single dose provides lifelong immunity.

Indications
  • Individuals traveling to endemic areas, including parts of Africa and South America.

Contraindications
  • Allergies to any component of the vaccine, especially egg proteins.
  • Immunocompromised
  • Infants under 6 months
  • Pregnancy: Generally avoided unless the risk is high.

Additional
  • Proof of vaccination (Yellow card) is required for entry into certain countries.

questions.text: Which of the following are the intermediate hosts of dracunculiasis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Cyclops

 

Explanation:

Cyclops are intermediate hosts of dracunculiasis (guinea-worm disease).

 

Cyclops:

 

Synonym
  • Water flea

Habitat
  • Freshwater

Morphology
  • Not more than 1 mm in length
  • Pear-shaped semi-transparent body
  • Forked tail
  • 2 pairs of antennae

Health Importance

  • Intermediate host of dracunculiasis [guinea-worm disease]
  • Transmit fish tapeworms [Diphyllobothrium latum]

Control measures
  • Straining and boiling water
  • Chemicals like chlorine, lime, and abate
  • Using barbel-gambusia fishes
  • Avoiding step wells

Sandfly (Option A) transmits leishmaniasis which is a protozoan disease most commonly seen in Europe, Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

 

Hard ticks (Option B) are vectors of many parasitic and bacterial infections like tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularaemia, and tick paralysis.


Soft ticks (Option C) transmit Q-fever, relapsing fever, and KFD.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer from a tropical region presented with chronic fatigue and pallor. There is a history of barefoot farming practices and frequent contact with soil contaminated by human feces. Laboratory tests revealed severe iron deficiency anemia. What number of eggs per gram of stool of this farmer makes this disease a major public health problem?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) >300

Explanation:

The farmer's symptoms of chronic fatigue, pallor, and severe iron deficiency anaemia, combined with the history of barefoot farming in contaminated soil, suggest hookworm infection. A Chandler’s index of >300 indicates it is a major public health problem.

 

Chandler’s index is an indicator for assessing the severity of ancylostomiasis based on the average number of hookworm eggs per gram of stools.

 

Average no. of eggs/g of stools

Significance

<200

Not of much importance

200-250

Indicates potential danger

250-300

Indicates minor public health problem

>300

Major public health problem
